articles.title: Jake Scott
articles.contents:
Jake Scott
          
          
          Home
          Projects
          CV
          â˜°
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Jake Scott
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        LinkedIn
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Twitter
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        GitHub
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Email
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            Welcome to my personal website! I currently work as a Community
            Development Analyst at the Federal Reserve Bank of New
            York. Here, I contribute to research/analytic projects on
            topics such as financing climate adaptation in the housing
            sector, building population health financing models, and
            ensuring widespread household financing well-being. I do so
            by working on every stage of the research and data analysis
            process; from building reliable and reusable data pipelines,
            to visualizing and analyzing complex data sets, to working
            with domain experts. I also conduct outreach and organize
            events that bring together policymakers, investors,
            advocates, and other stakeholders.
            I graduated in 2020 from Colgate University, where I
            studied economics and political science. It is there that I
            first fell in love with data science in general and with R
            in particular. Since then, I have done countless academic,
            professional, and personal projects using R, R Markdown, R
            Shiny, and amazing packages like {tidyverse}, {tidytext},
            {ggplot}, and more.
            Prior to my current position, I worked as a Senior
            Research Assistant for the Monetary
            Studies Section of the Federal Reserve Board, a research
            intern at the Hamilton Project at
            the Brookings Institution, as a data research intern at
            Burgiss, and as a
            data intern at the Data
            Collaboratory. I have also done work raising money as a
            student caller, doing research as a research assistant and
            coauthor, knocking on doors as a political canvasser, and
            teaching students as an economics tutor. The throughline for
            all of this work, as well as my personal projects, is a deep
            interest in using data to understand and impact the world,
            particularly in the realm of public policy and the
            economy.
            Outside of work and data, I enjoy reading, watching the
            Giants, Mets, and Sixers, and exploring NYC (run clubs,
            skeeball, board game cafes, and more). Please feel free to
            reach out if you have any questions about my work, if you
            think I could help your team, or if you just want to chat
            about R or anything else!
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Jake Scott
            
            
              
                
                                    
                    
                      LinkedIn
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      Twitter
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      GitHub
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      Email

articles.title: My Projects
articles.contents:
Shiny Apps Coronavirus Tracker Shiny App Shiny web app that allows users to see Covid-19 cases and deaths at the national, state, and county level. Prototype Spotify Analysis Application Shiny web app that allows user to input their Spotify username and analyze the characteristics of their music. Live 2020 Election Night Model Shiny web app that fed real-time election data into the Economist Election Model and presented the resulting live win probabilities by state. # Medium Articles {=html}

He Dies, She Sucks

An Analysis of Gender and Language in Songs on Spotify.


{=html}

What's in a Word?

Why tf-idf sometimes fails to accurately capture word importance, and what we can use instead.


Academic Articles (Not) Working 9 to 5: Using Music Characteristic and Song Lyric Data to Predict Initial Claims Explored whether the features and sentiment of popular music in a given week could predict initial claims, using Lasso. The Endogeneity of the Natural Rate of Growth in the United States Applied Okun's Equation and Thirlwall's Reversal Method to quarterly data on unemployment and gross domestic product in the United States from 1948 to 2019 in order to test the assumption that the natural rate of growth is exogenous to actual growth Measurement Sensitivity in Field-of-Study Mismatch Research Use data from the National Survey of College Graduates in simple linear regression and linear probability models to demonstrate that the predicted causes and consequences of field-of-study mismatch are highly sensitive to how one measures mismatch itself.
